column4: you have to highlight that partition and set for ex / as a mount point
you chose manual partition setup right?
is that a message for me, I am not sure what you mena. I did highlight, but dont know what setting ex for mount point means
how do I do that
<jakewc2>when you choose manual partition setup, highlight the old partition where ubuntu was. then i think you click on edit and set the mountpoint. i just chose / there.
for example you could set / as mount point. or if you had different root and home the tell it wich [artitions are the root and /home
one sec I'll take a pic, and show it to you
highlight the old ubuntu partition and click edit. tell it to use / as mount point. then click ok and next or whatever
boot the recovery console listen under your main kernel in your grub2 list and there is a repair packages option there
ok, I tried to tick on the ext4 partition, and I get an error saying 'No root File System, please correct this from partitioning menu' Can you tell me what that means please
tried to take a screen shot but wouldnt let me
try deleting it. then make a new ext4 partition there. and make it ext4 if you want
that womt work, tried it already, catestrophic error, nothing boots up, which is why I have to do a fresh install
sounds like there is just an ext4 partition thats boogered up there. use the partition manager to format it
what does it mean when it says 'no root filesystem'
use the live cd and gparted. delete that ext4 old ubuntu partition and make a new one
http://ubuntuforums.org/showthread.php?t=16710

see the part that says : ummm...theres somewhere it asks you about which partitions to mount where, in a list.... you should make sure the partition3 where you want to install linux is marked '/' instead of being something else....
ok, dont know what I did but had to change somethign, when I deleted it, then I actually found the / to start, and its now copying files. That is so confusing.
I deleted the partition that i want to install, then i restart the install and select "use continous free space".
Then it worked me.
